content.title: At Costa Verde, dream in a renovated plane

introduction.small: On Costa Rica's Pacific coast, two hours from the San José airport, Costa Verde offers a chance for an unusual night, in a restored Boeing 727.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Costa Verde, dream in a renovated plane

paragraphs.text:
In Quepos, small village near the Manuel Antonio Costa Rican national park, the Costa Verde Hotel settled in amid 30 hectares of preserved jungle. This natural corridor allows animals to easily reach the coastline, only a few metres away from the park. From the bedrooms, studios and bungalows, you will be able to observe the processions of squirrel monkeys, capuchins and other howler monkeys.
However, the hotel's main attraction is its airplane, suspended 15 metres above ground and looking like it is about to land in the tropical forest. Renovated into a two-room independent housing unit, this 1965 Boeing 727 reveals a 360° view of the beach and the nature reserve from the cockpit and windows. The wings, now covered by surrounding flora, have been arranged as sheltered terraces. As for the interior, it will remind you of a mountain cabin with its all-wood rustic style of decoration. Wake up at dawn to make the best of the panorama from the plane, then take a walk on the two private hiking trails to get as close to toucans and sloths as possible.

Costa Verde Hotel
Playas de Manuel Antonio, Km 5
Quepos
00011 Manuel Antonio
Provincia de Puntarenas

+506 2777 0584

www.costaverde.com

Rooms: from 60,500 CRC

content.title: Costa Rican heritage in the spotlight at Restaurante Silvestre

introduction.small: Amid the Barrio Amòn neighbourhood in San José, Restaurante Silvestre pays tribute to Costa Rica's cultural traditions and history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Costa Rican heritage in the spotlight at Restaurante Silvestre

paragraphs.text:
Situated in an 1860s Art Deco house, Restaurante Silvestre reinvents Costa Rican cuisine. Chef Santiago Fernández takes his inspirations straight from national heritage. Each dish is therefore a tribute to the country's traditions, for instance with small masked figurines placed next to every plate. Stemming from Pre-Columbian culture, they are called mantudos and are generally taken out during popular celebrations.
For the menu, the chef only uses local and seasonal products, sometimes organic but always ecologically friendly. Costa Rican specialities have been raised to the highest level of gastronomy. Try the enyucado – South American cake made of yucca and anise – with beef and yucca croquetes, or the catch of the day served with a palm heart purée and sundried tomatoes. Unless you have your heart set on the shoulder of lamb, roasted sweet potatoes and orange and fennel salad. Akin to its Belle Époque decoration including contemporary details, Santiago Fernández's cuisine subtly fuses present and past.

Restaurante Silvestre
Ave. 11 Calle 3A – 955
Barrio Amón
10101 San José
Provincia de San José

+506 2221 2465

www.restaurantesilvestre.com ﻿

Menu: around 20,000 CRC

content.title: The sulphurous ardour of the Poas volcano

introduction.small: I am near Alajuela, less than 50 kilometres from San José and at over 2,700 meters above sea level. Who am I? I am the volcano Poas and I still release vapours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The sulphurous ardour of the Poas volcano

paragraphs.text:
The famous stratovolcano of Costa Rica, Poas, has had several dozen eruptions since 1828 and it has been active, according to scientists, for more than 11 million years. In January 1910, it released a column of vapours and ashes up to 8,000 meters in height. Since then, its main crater has been home to an acid lake whose water apparently relieves muscle pain and treats wounds.

The Poas volcano still releases some fumaroles and sulphurous vapours, while it continues frequent phreatic eruptions similar to Geyser activity. The site is easily accessible and the proposed trails are numerous: ‘Sombrilla de Pobre', ‘Laguna Botos' or ‘Escalonia'. You can approach, with care, the gases that follow the internal slopes of the crater then slowly escape into the clear sky. A magical show!

Volcan Poas
Provincia de Alajuela

Tel : +506 2482 2165

www.costarica.fr/parc-national/poas

content.title: Explore the canals of Tortuguero

introduction.small: On the east coast of Costa Rica, long arms of golden water surround the national park and the village of Tortuguero. Explore the peaceful waters of this protected natural site.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the canals of Tortuguero

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of a tropical forest, canals and tawny rivers intertwine, home to Caribbean wildlife. A nesting place for sea turtles, Tortuguero National Park is hidden in the province of Limón, north of the Atlantic coast. It borders the eponymous village which, on the Brava border, is almost entirely supported by ecotourism and research. Many families rent cabins to visitors and sell products typical of the region. Settled onto a makeshift barque, you can sail between strangler figs and herbaceous lianas. Birds sing and insects stridulate around you.

By going to Cahuita or Puerto Viejo de Talamanca, you will discover the influences of the Bribri and Cabécar peoples in the sand-covered streets. A few steps away, the musical legacy of Puerto Limón thrills the marshes, beaches and lagoons around, reflecting the Creole melting pot of which the community is composed.

Tortuguero
Provincia de Limón

www.acto.go.cr/index.php/en/

content.title: Casa Marbella: a touch of the good life

introduction.small: At the heart of the village of Tortuguero, this charming yellow house hosts a dozen rooms and is a good base camp for exploring the surrounding National Park.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Marbella: a touch of the good life

paragraphs.text:
After exploring the jungle in the fabulous Tortuguero park and its mysterious canals and huge beaches where sea turtles come to lay their eggs, it is very nice to take a meditative break on the terrace of the Casa Marbella, just above the river. Water flows, the boats pass, colourful macaw couples fly off, howler monkeys utter their guttural cries, and time stretches to infinity. Or you could turn your attention elsewhere and watch visitors, families, kids, and dogs walking on the main street of the tiny village.

Between lagoon and Caribbean Sea, the Casa Marbella bed and breakfast, simple but comfortable, provides a ringside seat for watching the spectacle of life at the end of the world. And you can share the extraordinary events of the day (alligators, toucans, monkeys, iguanas...) with the other residents in a friendly, innocent, and intimate ambiance.

Casa Marbella
Tortuguero
Province de Limón

+506 8833 0827

http://casamarbella.tripod.com

Rooms: from 17,260 CRC

content.title: Watching turtles in Tortuguero

introduction.small: This is one of the best places in the world to witness the nesting of sea turtles, as many choose the Caribbean coast each year to lay their eggs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Watching turtles in Tortuguero

paragraphs.text:
Astride the land and the sea, the Tortuguero National Park is rare indeed: it is one of the leading regions in the world where four of the seven known species of sea turtles—leatherback, green, hawksbill, and olive ridley—lay their eggs. For more than 55 years, these beaches along the Caribbean Sea have been an unparalleled conservation area for protecting them.

Observing them is highly regulated and must be done with a guide, in small groups, at specific times and locations. It is an exceptional night show which requires discretion so as not to disturb these threatened or endangered species while they bury their eggs in the sand. They come from March to October, with peak attendance in summer—much like the visitors who come to see these special reptiles...

Tortuguero National Park
Provincia de Limón

+506 2710 2929

www.acto.go.cr

content.title: Arenal Volcano: a source of soothing thermal waters

introduction.small: Although dormant since 2010—but still under observation in case it wakes up again—the volcano continues to produce, in its depths, water with relaxing properties.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arenal Volcano: a source of soothing thermal waters

paragraphs.text:
In the area of the Arenal Volcano, rain, penetrating into the ground, meets the submerged magma, which heats it and loads it up with all kinds of minerals. The water then springs from the mountain side in the middle of the lush vegetation, to the delight of swimmers wading in ponds, pools, and streams that are natural or landscaped, with temperatures ranging from 25 to 50 degrees Celsius.

Some springs are free, others require payment. There are even some that are very luxurious, with spas, massages, and body treatments, such as the Springs Resort & Spa or the Tabacon Grand Spa Thermal Resort, both of which offer splendid views of the imposing cone of Arenal, to all appearances so calm but which, in reality, is boiling on the inside...

Volcan Arenal
Provincia de Alajuela

content.title: The coffee trail: from bean to cup

introduction.small: About 40 kilometres south of San José and 15 kilometres from Cartago, the Orosi Valley is known for its numerous coffee plantations, some of which are open to visitors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The coffee trail: from bean to cup

paragraphs.text:
In the centre of Costa Rica, many fincas (‘farms' in Spanish) and agricultural cooperatives grow coffee, which flourishes in the fertile volcanic soils of undulating plateaux. This special and flourishing terroir was discovered in the 19th century, nearly 100 years after coffee had been introduces into the country. Coffee production made landowning families rich. Today, cafetales, or ‘coffee plantations' open their doors to show the drink's production process, from the field to the cup, via drying and roasting. In January, there is even the feria del café, a festival devoted to the rich black liquid in Frailes, a village 40 kilometres west of Orosi. Professionals, amateurs, and tourists gather around a bean-harvest competition, religious ceremonies, the election of the Coffee Queen and, of course, tastings.

Vallée d'Orosi
Provincia de Cartago

content.title: Immerse yourself in the jungle at Pachira Lodge

introduction.small: Nestled in Tortuguero National Park, this hotel lives to the rhythms of both the forest and the turtles that come every year to lay their eggs on the beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Immerse yourself in the jungle at Pachira Lodge

paragraphs.text:
The bungalows, hidden under greenery, contain 88 simple and functional rooms that are convivial and environmentally friendly. The hotel team is devoted to the quality of their care but also to nature, which has offered Costa Rica a white flower growing on the pachira tree, which has given its name to this set of lodges.It has a pool shaped like a turtle—a nod to the surrounding stars, the sea turtles that visitors from around the world observe during the nesting season on the nearby beach

When the turtles are not there, guests are involved in wonderful activities, included in the holiday price (like the transportation to the hotel and full board): walks into the picturesque village of Tortuguero and in the forest, and exploration by boat of the canals of the national park, rich in wild fauna and flora. Pachira Lodge's main restaurant is installed outdoors, but is covered. Steps away from the jungle, you can thus enjoy the view of the canal while savouring the national cuisine, which is given pride of place for the various buffets of the day.

Pachira Lodge
70204 Tortuguero
Provincia de Limón

+506 2256 7080

www.pachiralodge.com

Rooms: from 132,170 CRC

content.title: The Central Market: colourful and flavourful

introduction.small: At the heart of San José, the Mercado Central is a concentration of Costa Rican crafts, souvenirs, vegetables, and exotic fruits.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Central Market: colourful and flavourful

paragraphs.text:
The main covered market, which is the largest in the capital, was established in 1880 and continues to thrive every day, except Sunday, from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00p.m. The people of San José, as well as tourists and casual visitors, flock to more than 200 shops and stalls for very comprehensive shopping: exotic fruits, vegetables bursting with vitamins, fresh meat and fish, colourful hammocks, locally produced coffees, spices, clothing, souvenirs, etc. All around, small cafés, called sodas in Costa Rica, serve home cooking with typical dishes like casado, which consists of rice, red beans, salad, and meat. Taken as a whole, the market gives a very good condensed overview of Costa Rican daily life, its diversity, and its natural, cultural, and culinary crafts.

Mercado Central
Avenida central, calle 6 y 8
San José

www.facebook.com/Mercado-Central-de-San-Jos%C3%A9-Costa-Rica-132271433523797/

content.title: Museum of Pre-Columbian gold: the riches of Costa Rica

introduction.small: The country is best known for its well-preserved fauna and flora. But it hides a treasure in the centre of the capital: the Museum of Pre-Columbian gold.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of Pre-Columbian gold: the riches of Costa Rica

paragraphs.text:
Columbus was not completely wrong when he decided to name the lands of Central America ‘Costa Rica', thinking they were full of gold. In reality, they were not as rich in the precious metal as he'd thought. Yet some 1,600 archaeological pieces have been dazzling visitors for 50 years, since the museum opened, under the authority of the central bank that owns it. They open up a window to the worldview of pre-Columbian peoples who shaped them between 500 BC and 1500 AD, as they reflect social structures, goldsmithing techniques, and the relationship of man with nature through, for example, many depictions of animals. The exhibition is completed by ancient coin collections, ceramics, and objects from the different ethnic peoples who have lived in Costa Rica.

Museo del Oro Precolombino
Calle 5
Plaza de la Cultura
San José

+506 2243 4202

museosdelbancocentral.org

content.title: Microbar:for its craft beers

introduction.small: This tiny establishment with original decor showcases fine beers produced in Costa Rica by quality microbrewers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Microbar:for its craft beers

paragraphs.text:
The cooling foam on the waves of the nearby Pacific does not reach the terrace of this little bar that openson to the street. But the Costa Rican beersescaping from pumps in a row behind the wooden counter and filling glasses with delicious amberprovide more than enough refreshment. ‘La Selva' (The Jungle),‘Fercas Brew House', ‘Tierra Fertil' and ‘La Bruja'are enjoyed while snacking on shrimp or a plate of meat and cheese.

The atmosphere is relaxed even if the context is revealed as at once trendy, stylish, retro, and unusual, with lily-patterned wallpaper, white tileslikethose in a Paris metro station, and old movie posters on the walls. Customers, perched on high stools lining the bar, do not see the time passing, despite the large Micro clock.

Microbar
Arriba Pathway
50201 Sámara
Provincia de Guanacaste

+506 8784 7467

facebook.com/microbar.samara/

Menu: around 7,000 CRC

content.title: Kalú: the pleasures of gathering together

introduction.small: At once a trendy restaurant and a ‘caféothèque' dedicated to Costa Rican products, this address is also distinguished by its sleek Zen design in a beautifully restored1950s' house.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kalú: the pleasures of gathering together

paragraphs.text:
Camille Ratton, a young Franco-Costa Rican chef, is passionate about Asian, Mediterranean, and Creole cuisine: they converge in the dishes she creates for Kalú, which means ‘meeting place' in the native language of Panama. Adept with quality products, she offers salmon and tuna ceviche or baked eggs for starters,Thai chicken or a mushroom risotto for the main, and, for dessert, a trio of crèmesbrûlées or panna cottas, a cheesecake with strawberries and balsamic vinegar, or a tarte tatin.

Conviviality is also expressed through sharedtapas (falafel, tacos, naans, patatas bravas) and space organised around a beautifully planted and furnished patio, with white walls, light wood, and contemporary paintings. Kalú is open for lunch and dinner during the week (closed Mondays), breakfast, brunch, and dinner on Saturdays, and breakfast and brunch on Sundays. Itsadjoining Caféothèque offers a fine selection of national coffees and enhances ‘coffee culture'... in every sense of the term.

Kalú
Calle 31, avenida 5
Barrio Escalante
San José

+506 2253 8426

www.kalu.co.cr

Menu: around 12,000 CRC

content.title: Punta Uvita: a meeting place for humpback whales

introduction.small: Most of the year, the huge whales migrate south along the Pacific coast of Costa Rica. From land or boat, meeting these marine mammals is magical.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Punta Uvita: a meeting place for humpback whales

paragraphs.text:
This is somehow a predestined spot: the shape of the small peninsula of Punta Uvita looks like a whale's tail. Humpbacks come just off the point to breed or give birth to calves in ideal waters, as the temperature is fairly constant, reaching 28 degrees Celsius! These visits last almost all year except in May and June: from December to April, they arrive in the northern hemisphere and from July to October, they go back to Antarctica. Given this near-constant migration, the area has been protected since 1989 with the creation of the Parque Nacional Marino Ballena, the country's first marine park. You can observe these 40-tonne creatures from the Pacific coast or approach them by boat (not too close though) during excursions organised by various agencies in the region. What a thrill to hear the love song of whales and see them jumping out of the ocean and falling back, slamming their gigantic tails in the waves!

Punta Uvita
Península de Osa
Provincia de Puntarenas

content.title: Alma de Café: a large supplement of soul

introduction.small: This elegant café in the majestic National Theatreoffers a pleasant break, with or without an accompanying performance, since it is open every day from morning to early evening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alma de Café: a large supplement of soul

paragraphs.text:
One of the most beautiful old buildings in the Costa Rican capital houses a retro café where coffee is king: it comes in dessert, ice cream, iced or classic espresso and cappuccino, from the best growths from seven provinces.

Though the building, built in the late 19th century, impresses with its exterior colonnade and marbles and frescoes inside, the kitchen opts for a simplicity that does not exclude quality: the sandwiches are prepared with homemade bread, salads with seasonal vegetables, smoked salmon, chicken, or tuna,and the quiche changes daily. There are also fruit cocktails that can be mixed with soy milk. An absolute must if you want to splurge in San José.

Alma de Café
Avenida 2, entre las calles 3 y 5
San José

+506 2010 1119

www.almadecafe.cr

Menu: around 6,200 CRC

content.title: Commune with nature at Tabacón Grand Spa Thermal Resort

introduction.small: Natural traditional rituals, luxury, and sustainable development make up the magic formula of this hotel, located at the foot of the majestic Arenal Volcano summit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Commune with nature at Tabacón Grand Spa Thermal Resort

paragraphs.text:
No nearby beach, certainly, but five hot springs(with a temperature between 25 and 50°C) with recognized therapeutic virtues provide relaxation and wellness. These beneficial sources feed the outdoor pools as well as the Grand Spa, which has 11 bungalows opening onto the rainforest and is a member of the Leading Spas of the World.

The five-star hotel is also a member of the Leading Hotels of the World consortium, which consists of 400 outstanding luxury accommodations around the world. Here, the 103 rooms and suites play upon discretion, with a classic and cosy setting, because the show is outdoors: on the slopes of the volcano and in the heart of nature's abundance, dotted with orchids and morphos, the typical electric blue butterflies of Costa Rica. The restaurants of this great spa resort, immersed in lush greenery, range from Ayurvedic dishes to chic Mexican street food.

Tabacón Grand Spa Thermal Resort
Arenal
21007 La Fortuna de San Carlos
Provincia de Alajuela

+506 2479 2099

www.tabacon.com

Rooms: from 170,000 CRC

content.title: Enjoy the hospitality of the Hotel Grano de Oro

introduction.small: Its name comes from the term for the Costa Rican coffee bean, and it is perfectly suited for this gem, which garners unanimous agreement among those seeking rare finds.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the hospitality of the Hotel Grano de Oro

paragraphs.text:
The capital of Costa Rica is gradually developing its offering of boutique accommodations, but it is not yet on par with some other cities of Central America. This probably explains the craze for this intimate address, with two Jacuzzis on the rooftop terrace and rooms overlooking the garden or a small private patio. Most feature​​ a rather refined white style, but the Garden Suites and the Vista de Oro are adorned with beautiful old woodwork.

This stylish retro cocoon takes you back a century, to the time of the construction of the house, built by a noble family, who happily combined Victorian architecture and tropical influences. You will find the same mix of styles in the restaurant, where the French Mediterranean cuisine is tinged with exotic flavours: vanilla salmon, lamb chops with a lemon and tomato sauce, or sea bass Provencal.

Hotel Grano de Oro
Calle 30, Avenida 2 y 4
San José

+506 2255 3322

www.hotelgranodeoro.com

Rooms: from 85,450 CRC

content.title: ‘Let's go surfing' at Playa Avellanas

introduction.small: Costa Rica is a popular destination for surfers from around the world, who come to challenge the Pacific rollers. Among the best spots is the Playa Avellanas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ‘Let's go surfing' at Playa Avellanas

paragraphs.text:
The Nicoya Peninsula is renowned throughout the world for its ideal surfing beaches, especially in the northern province of Guanacaste, near Tamarindo. That seaside resort is very popular with Americans, but the nearby beach of Avellanas is much quieter... at least on dry land! In the water, however, the waves crash openly and regularly.

Throughout the year, conditions remain very favourable, so that some call the place ‘Little Hawaii'. Other famous surfing spots punctuate the west coast of Costa Rica: Playa Hermosa and Jacó, each of which hosted the world surfing championships, in 2009 and in August 2016 respectively, and the beaches of Montezuma, Malpais, and Santa Teresa, in the southern part of the peninsula.

Playa Avellanas
Provincia de Guanacaste

content.title: Storming the Irazú Volcano

introduction.small: Costa Rica has many volcanoes, but some cannot be summited. However, despite its 3,432 metres, which makes it the highest of all, Irazú has been tamed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Storming the Irazú Volcano

paragraphs.text:
The strato volcano Irazústands proudly within the national park that bears its name. It looks impressive with its record height for Costa Rica and its three craters, the principal one being a kilometre in diameter and housing an acid lake of surreal colour. The summit, stripped bare and worthy of a lunar landscape, offers a breathtaking panorama.

The volcano has been dormant since 1965, before which time it had undergone two years of intense activity that caused particularly strong ash projections in the nearby capital during an official visit by US President John F. Kennedy. The first eruption, in turn, was recorded in 1723. Today, this behemoth remains under close surveillance because it could again honour the origin of its name: Irazúmeans ‘mountain of tremors and thunder' in the indigenous language.

Irazú Volcano
Provincia de Cartago

+506 2200 5025

content.title: Cafe & Macadamia: a snack for the road

introduction.small: On the Interamericana, the legendaryhighway connecting Panama to Alaska that runs through Costa Rica, this diner is a convenient and tasty halt between two tourist stops.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cafe & Macadamia: a snack for the road

paragraphs.text:
It may be at the edge of a busy road frequented by big American trucks, but this is not an ordinary roadside restaurant, as evidenced by its beautiful Spanish colonial architecture, its nice quiet terrace surrounded by a lush garden, and the macadamia shells littered everywhere by way of gravel. The house itself produces these nuts as well as the orchids you are invited to discover more closely in the adjoining farm.

The hearty dishes are prepared in the open kitchen, using local ingredients, most of which are organic. This is the case for traditional Costa Rican casado, a large dish made of rice, red beans, salad, and meat—or palm hearts for the vegetarian version. But you can also enjoy a refreshing gazpacho, well-garnished sandwiches with homemade bread, or huge cookies with chocolate and… macadamia nuts, of course! You can eat in, or take it on the road with you...

Cafe & Macadamia
Ruta 1
Sardinal
Provincia de Puntarenas

+506 2639 1036

www.facebook.com/pages/Cafe-Macadamia/1710430092537720

Menu: around 8,000 CRC

content.title: The Basilica of Cartago and the Black Madonna

introduction.small: The monumental Our Lady of the Angels is the most sacred building in Costa Rica. Every year, pilgrims flock to celebrate the Negrita, avenerated statue of the Virgin Mary.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Basilica of Cartago and the Black Madonna

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of Cartago, the former Costa Rican capital founded in the mid-16th century but ravaged by several volcanic eruptions and earthquakes, stands the magisterial Catholic basilica of Nuestra Señora de los Ángeles. This was built around 1639 in honour of the Black Madonna, or Negrita. The statue, exhibited in the interior of the building, watches over the whole country, of which she became the patron saint—it is even said that she has performed miracles. In thanks, a pilgrimage takes place on 2 August, involving nearly a million believers who travel the 20 kilometres between San José and the Cartago Basilica on foot.

The figure of Our Lady of the Angels is imposing and somewhat eclectic, because the architecture was redesigned overtime, after damage caused by the irascible Irazu volcano, which is nearby. Spanish colonial style with Byzantine influences now dominates, with, of course, domes and white columns.

Basilica Nuestra Señora de los Ángeles
Avenida 1 del Comercio
Provincia de Cartago
Cartago

+506 2551 0465

www.santuarionacional.org

content.title: Arenal Observatory Lodge & Spa: so close to the volcano

introduction.small: Located at the foot of the Arenal Volcano, southwest of La Fortuna, this is the only accommodation in the National Park. Perfect for a 100% natural experience!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arenal Observatory Lodge & Spa: so close to the volcano

paragraphs.text:
Spend the night as close as you can get to the dormant volcano... This National Park-authorised eco-lodge is for all budgets, since it offers not only dorm beds and double rooms but also bungalows for group stays with families or friends. All units comply with environmental rules imposed by the Costa Rican label for sustainable tourism, CST (Certificación para la Sostenibilidad Turística): the property is classified as level 3 of 5 by the organisation.

After hiking around nearby Lake Arenal, or taking a trip on the flanks of the volcano, you can relax in the hot tub and pool, fed by the hot thermal waters. Unless you should choose to watch the clouds brushing the silhouette of the mountains, which form an imposing green or greyed cone marked by ancient lava flows, through the bay windows of your room…

Arenal Observatory Lodge & Spa
Arenal
Province d'Alajuela

+506 2479 1070

www.arenalobservatorylodge.com

Rooms: from 49,550 CRC

content.title: Lazing on the beach in Sámara

introduction.small: This human-scale resort has kept the spirit of the town and is a restful stopover, courtesy of its large sandy beach on the Pacific Ocean.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lazing on the beach in Sámara

paragraphs.text:
The cove, set among green hills, forms a kind of cocoon for vacationers in search of serenity. Easily accessible, well served by transport infrastructures, offering a range of accommodations to suit all budgets, and dotted with restaurants, bars, cafés, and shops (including an organic grocery store), the village of Sámara will charm you with its relaxed and friendly atmosphere as much as it will by the frescoes of street art adorning its facades here and there. In addition, the town has the advantage of hidingits various buildings under the trees and vegetation, preserving the beauty of the coast. You can also contemplate the resort from the steep tiny island of Chora, which emerges on the left side of the beach, a headland that is particularly accessible for sea kayakers or stand-up paddlers because of the bay's calm waters.

Playa Sámara
Provincia de Guanacaste

content.title: Museum of Jade: green gold rush

introduction.small: If Costa Rica is renowned for being green, it's of course thanks to its prodigious flora—but it's also due to the splendid collections of San José's Museum of Jade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of Jade: green gold rush

paragraphs.text:
With its move to a modern building in 2014, the museum has further enhanced the showcasing of works and pieces of pre-Columbian jade (wrought between 500 BC and 800 AD). Divided into different themed rooms, the museum shows the various uses to which the gemstone was put in daily life (hunting, gathering), sacrifices, music, etc. Many pendants have a cutting bottom, like a chopper, while the upper part takes the form of human figures, birds, and reptiles. These objects are the artistic translation of the animist beliefs of the country's peoples, whose cultural and natural environment are also detailed in a museum enriched by a modern and educational display design. The role of shamans is particularly well defined: these religious leaders, intermediaries between the earthly world and that of the spirit, were said to have the power to transform themselves into animals, such as jaguars…

Museo del Jade
Avenida Central calle 13 y 13 bis
Plaza de la Democracia
San José

+506 2521 6610

www.museodeljadeins.com

content.title: Meeting in Rio Perdido

introduction.small: Immersed in vegetation at the edge of a canyon, this hotel respects the environment and integrates itself into the abundance of nature, which supplies it with thermal waters for relaxation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meeting in Rio Perdido

paragraphs.text:
Set in a private nature reserve, this jewel of a design hotel shines for its welcome at the foot of the Miravalles Volcano in the Cordillera de Guanacaste. The 20 bungalows with contemporary, colourful decor nestle in the rainforest, which may be explored via a path through the canopy to observe the teeming fauna and flora, or trekking along suspension bridges. These span the rivers, but you can go down from them to bathe in the water and the natural hot pools. They are the result of volcanic activity nearby, which also supplies the Hotel Spa. Provisions for the restaurant are also local, fresh and tasty, constituting the ingredients for ceviches, fajitas and light salads. A secret haven for a return to well-being and the pleasures of admiring nature.

Rio Perdido
San Bernardo de Bagaces
50401 Bagaces
Provincia de Guanacaste

+506 2673 3600

www.rioperdido.com

Rooms: from 151,033 CRC

content.title: MyCoffee: flavours of the Americas

introduction.small: Modern and friendly, this café-bar-restaurant is a must for both passing visitors and Costa Ricans, all of whom receive ringside seats to observe local life and the Arenal Volcano.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MyCoffee: flavours of the Americas

paragraphs.text:
It's always time for MyCoffee, located just off of Central Park, a small lively public square in La Fortuna. From morning to night, the colourful little room opening onto the covered terrace overlooking the street is always conducive to a gourmet break. The Costa Rican coffee in the cups steams, accompanied by pancakes for breakfast.

American specialties, from the north to the south of the continent coexist on the menu: shrimp ceviche and fish, fajitas, nachos, coconut curry chicken or skewers with pineapplesweet and sour sauce... Drinks include ‘batidos', delicious Costa Rican smoothies with exotic fruits, alongside national beer, Imperial,and craft beer brewed by the café itself. At lunchtime, the friendly restaurant also offers complete packages with an excellent value for money ratio.

MyCoffee
142, Alajuela, entre las calles 468 y 470
21007 La Fortuna de San Carlos
Provincia d'Alajuela

+506 2479 8749

www.mycoffeecr.com

Menu: around 5,000 CRC

content.title: Hike to the summit of Cerro Chirripó

introduction.small: The highest point in Costa Rica is a good goal for hikers, who must walk several days before being rewarded with a fantastic view at the top.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hike to the summit of Cerro Chirripó

paragraphs.text:
In the centre of the country, in the Talamanca Range, the 3,820-metre-highCerro Chirripó dominates the national park, established in 1975 and stretching over 50,000 hectares, that bears its name. You gradually pass througha wide variety of landscapes (and therefore wildlife) during the ascent, which is long and quite hard. The vegetation slowly withers, the rocks and the cold creating an inhospitable environment for plant life.

After the effort, the summit looks a bit like the Andes Cordillera, and in good weather it offers an extraordinary view, not only of the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea, but also everything else that surrounds it: the nearby glacial lakes and the 60-metre-tall Los Crestones (unique rocky outcroppings), which look like the petrified fingers of giants, or, further, the volcanoes of the central chain, such as Irazu, Poas, and Turrialba.

Parque nacional Chirripó
Provincias de San José, Limón y Cartago

+506 2742 5097

www.facebook.com/parquenacional.chirripo/

content.title: Tours of the rainforest canopy in Monteverde

introduction.small: Glide on zip lines and cross suspension bridges high above the ground and amidst the trees of the tropical rainforest for summit meetings with fauna and flora.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tours of the rainforest canopy in Monteverde

paragraphs.text:
In recent years, rainforest canopy tours, with zip lines and suspension bridges, have flourished in Costa Rica. The first were set up in the Monteverde area. They make it possible to get up high and go from tree to tree to benefit from a unique perspective, away from the level of the cows, to observe the dense life that prevails in the foliage.

The ‘cloud forest' of Monteverde (‘bosque nuboso' in Spanish), also called the ‘tropical high forest', is home to over 3,200 species of plants, 700 kinds of trees, and 500 types of orchids, flowers that notably attract hummingbirds. This unique ecosystem is due to moisture and fog prevailing in the area at the confluence of air currents from the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea.

Monteverde
Provincia de Puntarenas

content.title: Gusto Beach: a touch of Saint-Tropez

introduction.small: With a dream location on the beach, this sporting club bar-restaurant under the coconut trees is one of the ‘musts' of Sámara, a quiet village on the Pacific coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gusto Beach: a touch of Saint-Tropez

paragraphs.text:
Much less chic and exclusive than its distant Tropezien cousin, the legendary Club 55 on Pampelonne Beach, the Gusto Beach bar still features the same dominant white, the wooden countertop and furniture, as well as the hammocks and canvas folding chairs. It is also set in the sand, with the Pacific Ocean on the horizon rather than the Mediterranean Sea.

It nevertheless features prominently on the restaurant scene with pasta, salads and seafood on offer. But thisvery well located, trendy address in the centre of Sámara is also recommended for its happy-hour cocktails at sunset, concerts under the coconut trees, and numerous sporting activities on the beach, including surfing, beach volleyball, and beach tennis. There is something for every taste…

Gusto Beach
50201 Sámara
Provincia de Guanacaste

+506 2656 0252

www.facebook.com/pg/Gusto-Beach-Samara-123193624425053/

Menu: around 7,500 CRC

content.title: Parque Nacional Los Quetzales: in search of the sacred bird

introduction.small: Emblematic of Central America, the quetzal is becoming rare because its feathers have long been sought for ceremonial adornments. It has, for over ten years, benefitted from a protected area.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Parque Nacional Los Quetzales: in search of the sacred bird

paragraphs.text:
On the western side of the Talamanca mountain range, the park's altitude (between 1,240 and 3,190 metres above sea level) provides a refuge for the quetzal, which is a threatened species. The bird remains a strong symbol for the cultures of Central America: it's the emblem of Guatemala, the bird to which the Mayans and Aztecs devoted a famous cult, and the incarnation of the Mexican god Quetzalcoatl, the famous feathered serpent...

As for Costa Rica, it has given the quetzal this protected area of 117 hectares. Interested amateurs and passionate bird lovers alike go to the heart of the jungle and cloud forest to observe the red and vivid green of its long tail feathers. Those lucky enough to spot one feel blessed by the gods.

Parc national Los Quetzales
Provincia de San José

+506 2200 5354

content.title: Diving around Isla del Caño

introduction.small: This tiny island, a Biological Reserve just 15 kilometres from the coast, is the ideal place in Costa Rica to enjoy the undersea richness of a world of silence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Diving around Isla del Caño

paragraphs.text:
Boasting royal parrots, dolphins, turtles, manta rays, hammerhead sharks, mackerel, eel, and coral (18 species recorded in total), the underwater biodiversity of this tiny Pacificis land is absolutely fascinating. It can bed is covered with mask and fins for some simple snorkelling not far from the beaches, or with air tanks that allow visits to the many surrounding rock formations.

The value of Isla del Caño is all the greater, as Costa Rica has few diving spots; the Caribbean side is not easily walkable, and the country's other exceptional site, the Isla del Coco (600 species of molluscs, 300 species of fish and 32 species of coral), a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is lost in the Pacific more than 500 kilometres offshore. This latter, much less accessible spot is reserved for true enthusiasts and the very experienced.

Isla del Caño
Provincia de Puntarenas

content.title: Casa Esmeralda:just like home

introduction.small: In Sámara, thisrestaurant offers classical Costa Rican home cooking,executed flawlessly and prepared with fresh products.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Esmeralda:just like home

paragraphs.text:
Though the tables do not give directly onto the Pacific Ocean (although very close), it is invited onto the plates with beautiful proposals for seafood, shrimp salad,andceviche. The menu is typically Costa Rican (rice with shrimp or chicken, avocado salad, caramelized pineapple), with some international incursions expanding the possibilities, such as chicken curry or pasta dishes (with a shrimp and avocado sauce, for example).

Enjoy these specialties atnoon and at night in the pleasant dining room on the terrace outside the entrance or, under coverupstairs, in one of five adjoining rooms that can be rented for a small fee. Casa Esmeralda is an address that reflects the sodas, the typical restaurants of Costa Rica. This is certainly a safe bet for the resort town of Sámara.

Casa Esmeralda 
Centre-ville
50201 Sámara
Provincia de Guanacaste

+506 2656 0489

www.isamara.co/esmeralda/index.htm

Menu: around 9,500 CRC

content.title: Restore yourself at Springs Resort & Spa

introduction.small: This five-star hotel enjoys a privileged location facing the Arenal Volcano, which provides its healing thermal waters in a fascinating landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Restore yourself at Springs Resort & Spa

paragraphs.text:
The hotel complex, located 600 metres above sea level, is large, but it remains on a human scale because its 74 rooms, suites, and villas, all of which look to the craggy silhouette of the Arenal Volcano, are spread out over the lush slopes. These slopes are punctuated by thermal pools and hot-water torrents that emerge from the depths of the earth. They provide relaxation after hiking in the forest—on foot or horseback—or visiting the hotel's shelter for wild animals (home to toucans, crocodiles, pumas, and monkeys), or rafting in the neighbouring rivers. Unless, that is, you prefer to opt for the facility's spa, with sauna, steam, and massage rooms. Epicureans will also delight in the wide gastronomic offerings, including five different tables featuring a sushi bar and a chic panoramic restaurant, which seems to actually float in the canopy.

Springs Resort & Spa
Arenal
21007 La Fortuna de San Carlos
Provincia de Alajuela

+506 2401 3313

www.thespringscostarica.com

Rooms: from 252,790 CRC

content.title: Unwindat Punta Islita

introduction.small: This small eco-resort overlooks the beach from the heights of the Pacific coast. Its rooms and villas, buried under vegetation, are resolutely turned towards the ocean and loved by surfers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Unwindat Punta Islita

paragraphs.text:
Simplicity and authenticity prevail in this very comfortable hotel with delicate Spanish colonial touches. The same atmosphere is found in the rooms, where the junior suites have whirlpools. There are also casitas and villas, each with private plunge pools. The houses overlooking Islita beach, which have two or three bedrooms, are a boon for families or groups of friends, thanks to their low rates.

The large pool seems to extend over the bay and even dive into the waves. At the edge of the pool, the restaurant, covered with a palm-leaf roof and overlooking the clear horizon of the Pacific, offers fresh local cuisine, while body treatments and massages provided at the spa complement this muy bonito stay at Islita Bonita.

Hotel Punta Islita
Islita Beach
Guanacaste
50201 Sámara
Provincia de Guanacaste

+506 2656 3500

www.hotelpuntaislita.com

Rooms: from 145,230 CRC

content.title: Cahuita: the Caribbean version of Costa Rica

introduction.small: This village on the eastern coast is marked by Afro-Caribbean influences; it's a cultural singularity complemented by the natural features of an offshore coral reef.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cahuita: the Caribbean version of Costa Rica

paragraphs.text:
There are few places in which to swim on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica because of strong currents, sharks, tree trunks, and sediment carried by the rivers rushing down from the central volcanic chain. Yet there is a haven, in the south of the country, where the sea protects us from all these dangers. Around Cahuita, is the national park of the same name, which houses swamp forests as well as coral reefs that can be explored by snorkelling, and a black sand beach, aptly named ‘Playa Negra'.

The small town of Cahuita has another feature: its large Afro-Caribbean community. It is made up of descendants of Jamaican workers employed there more than a century ago for railway construction and work in the Costa Ricanbanana plantations. Creole cooking, reggae, wooden buildings on stilts, and colourful bungalows all contribute to the visitor's pervasive sense of being elsewhere…

Cahuita
Provincia de Limón

content.title: Yoga on Playa Hermosa

introduction.small: The ‘beautiful beach', as the Spanish name suggests, is not only a key spot for experienced surfers—it's also a privileged place to practise yoga.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yoga on Playa Hermosa

paragraphs.text:
Costa Rica's motto (‘Pura Vida', the ‘Good Life') is not an empty phrase. It is a philosophy that encourages the enjoyment of life while respecting the environment and staying connected to the generous and fabulous nature of this small country. It is therefore not surprising that yoga is easily implanted in this context, imported by surfers who practise Zen when they're not riding the ocean's rollers.

The eight-kilometre Playa Hermosa is a perfect cocoon for taking yoga classes with your feet in the sand, meditating on the view of the Pacific horizon. Or you can go there for a retreat at, for example, the Vida Asana Retreat Center, an eco-resort submerged under tropical vegetation, directly above the beach.

Playa Hermosa
Provincia de Puntarenas

content.title: Café Miel Garage: a restorative taste

introduction.small: With three addresses in San José, this small, local institution specializes in sweets, drinks, and gourmet cakes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café Miel Garage: a restorative taste

paragraphs.text:
There are three ‘Honey Garage' cafeterias in the Costa Rican capital, and the one in the Barrio Amón, in the heart of this trendy area between art galleries and lovely shops, sports the best location. The tiny space, open to the street, attracts passers-by with its small window displaying irresistible pastries: chocolate cake, cookies, wafers, etc.

The (very) rich coffees, hot or iced, are accompanied by caramel popcorn, ice cream, or sorbets. Among the other drinks displayed on the slate at the entrance are chocolates, teas, lemonades, and fruit juices. Except during Sunday closing, they can be tasted from the morning until 6:00p.m.amidst skateboards and brightly coloured graphic posters on the walls.

Café Miel Garage
Avenida 9, entre las calles 9 y 11
Barrio Amón
San José

www.cafemielgarage.com/

Menu: around 3,000 CRC

content.title: Observe wildlife at the San Luis Ecolodge

introduction.small: This former scientific camp now hosts students and tourists exploring the wilderness reserves in the Monteverde area, which is covered by both cloud forests and montane forests.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Observe wildlife at the San Luis Ecolodge

paragraphs.text:
In Costa Rica, this satellite of the State University of Georgia (UGA) isn't exactly your typical American university campus... Surrounded by rainforest, it opens up to sustainable-tourism enthusiasts who like to learn while travelling. You cohabit and can thus talk with the students, teachers, and scientists working permanently on the site.

Activities include the observation of birds, plants, and insects, and educational walks in the botanical garden, the coffee plantation, or the organic farm. So the curious will certainly have their fill! You stay, full board, in one of 12 rustic but functional rooms, each with a private bathroom. The interior of the lodge is all warm wood, while a balcony full of rocking chairs allows you to meditate upon the beauty of Costa Rican nature. You will really feel in the heart of the wild forest here.

Ecolodge San Luis
UGA Costa Rica
San Luis
60109 Monteverde
Provincia de Puntarenas

+506 2645 7363

www.ecolodgesanluis.com

Rooms: from 47,760 CRC

content.title: Barrio Amón: the soul of San José

introduction.small: This small area of the Costa Rican capital seduces with its old buildings, its atmosphere that is at once retro and trendy, and its great restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Barrio Amón: the soul of San José

paragraphs.text:
A modern city of over 300,000 inhabitants, the capital of Costa Rica hides a little nugget in its heart, the Amón district, which is full of charmon a human scale. The old houses built by wealthy families in the 19th and early 20th centurieshave not been eroded by standardized structures, and it is very pleasant to take the time to discover edifices with classical, colonial, and Victorian styles.

These beautiful buildings have been taken over by family hotels, art galleries, trendy shops—like eñe, a contemporary concept store dedicated to Costa Rican designers and creators—but also bars, cafés, and restaurants, which are among the best in the city and even the country. The architectural stroll and the shopping spree then combine to become a magnificent gourmet walk.

Barrio Amón
San José

content.title: Explore the city from Hotel Santo Tomas

introduction.small: Not far from the city centre, this small family-run hotel offers excellent value for money for visitors passing through San José.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the city from Hotel Santo Tomas

paragraphs.text:
Although located in the trendy Barrio Amón near the zoo and the botanical gardens, this imposing century-old building, enlarged with newer parts, harmoniously combines colonial and modern touches, whether in public areas (porch, terraces, or living room) or in the particularly spacious rooms.

The classic style of the establishment does not prevent it from offering every modern comfort, from the fitness room to the pool, which is complemented by a small slide and a hot tub, and is installed in the courtyard. Not to mention the restaurant attached to the hotel and the excursions organised on request by the hotel staff, who offer a friendly welcome to visiting guests. It is a good and very practical base for discovering the 1,001 wonders of Costa Rica, or a source of respite before taking the plane back home...

Hotel Santo Tomas
Avenida 7, entre las calles 3 y 5
San José

+506 2255 0448

www.hotelsantotomas.com

Rooms: from 30,800 CRC

content.title: Rafting and kayaking in the Sarapiquí River Valley

introduction.small: The lively, rapid waters of the Sarapiquí River, fed all year by rainfall, are appropriate for adventurers of all levels who wish to navigate between banks overgrown with tropical vegetation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rafting and kayaking in the Sarapiquí River Valley

paragraphs.text:
The ‘Pura Vida'(‘Good Life') in Costa Rica is not, as the saying goes, a long, quiet river... to the delight of kayakers, white-water rafters, and those who enjoy ‘tubing' (using large inner-tubes as flotation devices). The country is well watered by rains throughout the year and completely crisscrossed by rivers and small streams, some of which are great for turbulent water activities. These are practised through courses for beginners, or outings accompanied by a guide--at full speed for the thrill, or more calmly to take the time to observe the rich fauna and flora on the banks of the Rio Sarapiquí. Another very famous descent is the Rio Pacuare, further south. You will never tire of rowing, in joy and good humour.

Rio Sarapiquí
Provincia de Heredia

content.title: Remain speechless at El Silencio Lodge & Spa

introduction.small: The only Relais & Châteaux member in Costa Rica is only a half hour from San José's international airport, but it transports visitors to a place where everything is better.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Remain speechless at El Silencio Lodge & Spa

paragraphs.text:
Hidden in the centre of Costa Rica, close to the volcanic chain that crosses the country, this warm and elegant eco-lodge has 14 suites—each with a wooden terrace sheltering a hot tub—overlooking the abundant vegetation, mountains, and sometimes the river. Their classic colonial style is also found in the spacious two-bedroom family villas.

Surrounding the property are the jungle, waterfalls, and the organic vegetable gardens and orchards that supply the restaurant. You will find the same quality and concern for health at the spa, whose conical room is open to the forest in order to capture the vibrant energy. In addition to the treatments and massages, yoga is also practised here in serenity. Activities include rafting, hiking, and horseback riding, especially to the beautiful La Promesa waterfall… An address that lives up to all expectations!

El Silencio Lodge & Spa
Bajos del Toro
21203 Sarchí Norte
Provincia de Alajuela

+506 2476 0303

www.elsilenciolodge.com

Rooms: from 140,000 CRC

content.title: Corcovado: virgin forest in all its splendour

introduction.small: Corcovado National Park, on the Pacific side's Osa Peninsula, is home to many endangered species as it is one of the wildest parks in the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Corcovado: virgin forest in all its splendour

paragraphs.text:
Created in 1975, this vast national park of 42,000 hectares, of which there are 5,000 in the maritime domain, has absolutely fabulous biodiversity. Its primary rainforest, beaches, and coral reefs are inhabited by 71 species of reptiles, 124 species of terrestrial mammals (including howler monkeys, spider monkeys, and capuchins),and 375 different types of birds. Besides, of course, dozens of bat species, freshwater fish and sea turtles... Accompanied by a guide, you will observe this natural magnificence by walking trails through dense jungle or along the coast, hemmed in by the waves of the Pacific Ocean. It's a truly unique experience in an unspoiled area protected from classical tourism.

Parque nacional Corcovado
Provincia de Puntarenas

+506 2735 5580

content.title: Las Ventanas: window on the jungle

introduction.small: This gastro-chic restaurant at the Springs Resort & Spa delights diners with its fusion cuisine and its impressive panorama of volcanic and forest landscapes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Las Ventanas: window on the jungle

paragraphs.text:
The pleasures of the eyes and the taste buds enter into communion in this restaurant's large, elegantly furnished dining room, which features large windows affording beautiful views of the river and surroundingtropical vegetation. There is also the promise of a gourmet dinner, starting with, for example, a duo of gazpacho, a vegetable soup, a beef tartar sprinkled with grana padano, or papaya and shrimp salad. One or the other will be followed by top-flight pasta: handmade spaghetti with squid ink and scallops on the half shell, lobster ravioli, or ravioli with ricotta and pesto. Unless, that is, you prefer the sea bass with vegetables, a conger eel fillet with curry and coconut accented quinoa, or lemon chicken supreme, with oregano and rice pilaf. Que rico! as the Costa Ricans say.

Las Ventanas
Arenal
21007 La Fortuna de San Carlos
Provincia d'Alajuela

+506 2401 3310

www.thespringscostarica.com/dining_cocktails.php

Menu: around 20,000 CRC

content.title: Café Mundo: a cosmopolitan table

introduction.small: This century-old house in the Barrio Otoya has been turned into a cosy bar-restaurant where the customers are as international as the cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café Mundo: a cosmopolitan table

paragraphs.text:
Well hidden behind tall bamboo and a grey fence, Café Mundo is a must in the Costa Rican capital, especially for expatriates, who appreciate its classic colonial architecture, enhanced with a red facade, green shutters, and white valances. The colours are also bold inside with frescoes and tapestries on the walls, giving the place a certain class and a slightly old-fashioned feel.

While the dishes are very much in tune with the times, and even the open sea, they travel around the world: bruschetta, vegetable tempura, onion rings, and crab spring rolls, for starters; Caesar and Nicoise salads, pizza, pasta, empanadas, and Argentinian grill for the mains; pecan pie, tiramisu, flan with caramel, or chocolate mousse for dessert. No need for a passport to delight the taste buds!

Café Mundo
Avenida 9, calle 15
Barrio Otoya
San José

+506 2222 6190

www.facebook.com/CAFE-MUNDO-229711157070795/

Menu: around 10,000 CRC

content.title: Reach for the sky at the Four Seasons

introduction.small: Perched on a peninsula bordered by two beaches, this is one of the most luxurious hotels in Central America. Boredom is not on the menu at in activity-filled resort.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Reach for the sky at the Four Seasons

paragraphs.text:
Though well isolated on Peninsula Papagayo, guests here do not live like hermits in the 182 rooms (including 24 suites and 34 villas) scattered over a vast area of 930 hectares. Pools, restaurants (local or Italian, for example), and spa (near an 18-hole golf course) are all excuses to get out and enjoy the ‘Pura Vida', the unofficial currency of Costa Rica.

Aquatic sports fans also have the choice of sea kayaking, surfing, stand-up paddling, snorkelling, or fishing off the coast. Unless you prefer sitting down to stargaze, bird watch, or just admire the waves of the ocean. The interior design also oscillates between classic and modern, with soft tones and pop colours that are always reflective of the spirit of luxury and comfort.

Four Seasons
26 kilometres north of the Do It Centre
Península de Papagayo
5000 Carrillo
Provincia de Guanacaste

+506 2696 0000

www.fourseasons.com/costarica/

Rooms: from 358,540 CRC
